Roman.name: Rome
Roman.description: The capital city of the Roman Republic and the center of political, cultural, and military power. Key events include the assassination of Julius Caesar in 44 BCE and the subsequent rise of Augustus.

Roman.name: Pompeii
Roman.description: A thriving Roman city that was buried under volcanic ash after the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 CE, providing a well-preserved snapshot of Roman life.

Roman.name: Carthage
Roman.description: Formerly the center of the powerful Carthaginian Empire, Carthage was destroyed by Rome in 146 BCE during the Third Punic War and later rebuilt as a Roman city.

Gallic.name: Alesia
Gallic.description: The site of the decisive battle in 52 BCE where Julius Caesar defeated the Gallic tribes led by Vercingetorix, leading to the Roman conquest of Gaul.

Gallic.name: Gergovia
Gallic.description: A fortified city in Gaul where Vercingetorix achieved a significant victory against Julius Caesar in 52 BCE, though it was not enough to stop the Roman advance.

Gallic.name: Bibracte
Gallic.description: A major center of the Aedui tribe and the site of Caesar's victory over the Helvetii in 58 BCE. It also served as the location where Caesar wrote his 'Commentaries on the Gallic War'.

Egyptian.name: Alexandria
Egyptian.description: The capital city of Ptolemaic Egypt, founded by Alexander the Great. It was a major center of Hellenistic culture and learning, home to the famous Library of Alexandria and the Pharos lighthouse.

Egyptian.name: Memphis
Egyptian.description: An ancient capital of Egypt, located near the apex of the Nile Delta. During the late Republic, it remained an important religious and cultural center.

Egyptian.name: Thebes
Egyptian.description: A major city in Upper Egypt, known for its grand temples and as a center of worship for the god Amun. It was also a significant site for royal burials in the Valley of the Kings.
